pr_title: [JENKINS-61166] Show on 'updates' tab when a warning would be fixed

timeline.message: [JENKINS-61161] Show on 'updates' tab when a warning would be fixed
[JENKINS-61166] Show on 'updates' tab when a warning would be fixed
[JENKINS-61166] Show on 'updates' tab when a warning would be fixed

timeline.body: NIT: Maybe this variable should be named `addressesActiveVuln` or something to that effect and have its values reversed in this function so that it matches the javadoc
timeline.bodyText: NIT: Maybe this variable should be named addressesActiveVuln or something to that effect and have its values reversed in this function so that it matches the javadoc
timeline.bodyHTML: NIT: Maybe this variable should be named addressesActiveVuln or something to that effect and have its values reversed in this function so that it matches the javadoc
timeline.author: res0nance

replies.bodyText: I also find it quite confusing. In the theory in case there is a warning for an individual plugin, then the whole message should be displayed? I think this is actually doing the opposite?
replies.author: varyvol

timeline.body: NIT: Maybe this `VersionNumber` object should be constructed outside the loop. Although java might just optimize this away
timeline.bodyText: NIT: Maybe this VersionNumber object should be constructed outside the loop. Although java might just optimize this away
timeline.bodyHTML: NIT: Maybe this VersionNumber object should be constructed outside the loop. Although java might just optimize this away
timeline.author: res0nance

timeline.body:
NIT: due to the length / complexity of the line, it could be useful to put it into a variable. This could also help a bit the debugging.

```suggestion
            List<Warning> activePluginWarnings = ExtensionList.lookupSingleton(UpdateSiteWarningsMonitor.class).getActivePluginWarningsByPlugin().getOrDefault(installed, Collections.emptyList())
            for (Warning warning : activePluginWarnings) {
```
timeline.bodyHTML:
NIT: due to the length / complexity of the line, it could be useful to put it into a variable. This could also help a bit the debugging.

Suggested change
for (Warning warning : ExtensionList.lookupSingleton(UpdateSiteWarningsMonitor.class).getActivePluginWarningsByPlugin().getOrDefault(installed, Collections.emptyList())) {
List<Warning> activePluginWarnings = ExtensionList.lookupSingleton(UpdateSiteWarningsMonitor.class).getActivePluginWarningsByPlugin().getOrDefault(installed, Collections.emptyList())
for (Warning warning : activePluginWarnings) {
timeline.author: Wadeck

timeline.body:
NIT: Not used to such naming convention. I generally expect method starting with an action verb to do something. In this case if I call this method I expect it to fix the vulnerabilities.

💡 containsSecurityVulnerabilitiesFixes ?
